statement.p:
We have established that for f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x}, the degree n Taylor polynomial approximation centered at a = 0 is
T_n(x) = 1 + x + x^2 + \cdots + x^n .

li.p: Determine the exact value (as a fraction) of T_1\left( \frac{1}{2} \right), T_2\left( \frac{1}{2} \right), T_3\left( \frac{1}{2} \right), and T_4\left( \frac{1}{2} \right). How does each compare to the exact value of f\left( \frac{1}{2} \right)?

Explain why T_n\left( \frac{1}{2} \right) is a finite geometric series by identifying a and r, and then use Equation to find a single fraction that represents the sum given by T_n\left( \frac{1}{2} \right).

Now think more generally and explain why T_n\left( x \right) is a finite geometric series by identifying a and r, and then use Equation to find a single fraction that represents the sum given by T_n\left( \frac{1}{2} \right).

If we let the Taylor polynomial T_n(x) = 1 + x + x^2 + \cdots + x^n continue indefinitely, we get what we will call a Taylor series. Here we let
T(x) = 1 + x + x^2 + \cdots + x^n + \cdots . Explain why this infinite series is geometric, identify a and r, and use Equation to find the sum of the series as a function of x that is expressed as a single fraction. For which values of x is this sum valid? What do you notice about this expression for T(x)?
What is the domain of the function f(x) = \frac{1}{1-x}? How is this connected to your work in (d)?
